FeOx clusters confined in ZSM-5 as a high-performance catalyst for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis of lower hydrocarbons Qichao Lu Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Jie Li Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision Investigation Chen Liang Software Investigation Lei Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Jinxiang Dong Supervision Formal analysis Conceptualization College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan 030024 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan 030024, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Under the dual pressures of oil depletion and low-carbon transition, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) technology offers a viable option for producing high value-added lower (C2-C4) hydrocarbons from non-oil sources. However, conventional Fe-based catalysts often suffer from deactivation due to carbon deposition and sintering. Here, we report a unique Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst synthesized by doping Fe into ZSM-5, which demonstrates excellent FTS catalytic performance. During high-temperature template removal, Fe species migrated from the zeolite framework to form highly dispersed FeOx clusters (∼2 nm). Upon treatment by syngas, these FeOx clusters aggregate to form uniformly small-sized Fe5C2@C core-shell particles distributed on ZSM-5 support. The confinement effect of the inter-crystalline structure effectively prevents the sintering of Fe5C2. The smaller Fe5C2 particles exhibit controlled CO dissociation, reducing the concentration of activated carbon species (C*), and the carbon shells (∼6.5 nm) limit the departure of C*, effectively suppressing carbon deposition. This unique structure enables stable catalytic activity for over 100 hours with maintained product selectivity. The Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst achieved a C2-C4 hydrocarbons selectivity of 54.52 %, nearing the 56 % theoretical limit of the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution. Additionally, the hydrophobic carbon shell prevents excessive oxidation of Fe5C2, reducing CO2 selectivity by ∼56 % compared to conventional Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts, significantly enhancing atomic utilization efficiency and aligning with the principles of green development. Graphical Abstract The migration of Fe species in Fe-ZSM-5 by post-treatment could construct well-defined Fe5C2@C nanostructures on the ZSM-5 matrix, exhibiting exceptional catalytic performance in FTS, characterized by enhanced stability, minimized CO2 selectivity, superior carbon deposition resistance. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Fe-ZSM-5 Framework Fe migration Fe5C2@C C2-C4 hydrocarbons Carbon deposition suppression Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction C2-C4 hydrocarbons are essential chemical feedstocks for the production of plastics, rubber, resins, lubricating oil additives, and other bulk chemicals [1,2], playing a vital role in industrial and agricultural applications. Traditionally, C2-C4 hydrocarbons have been primarily derived from petroleum cracking [3] and the cracking of long-chain hydrocarbons. However, the depletion of oil resources, coupled with global instability [4–6] and environmental concerns related to greenhouse gas emissions [7], has driven the search for alternative carbon sources. FTS, a technology that transforms syngas—produced from coal, natural gas, or biomass—into valuable hydrocarbon products and fuels [8], offers a promising route for producing C2-C4 compounds without relying on petroleum. FTS catalysts are typically based on transition metals such as Ru, Fe, and Co [9,10]. Among these, Fe-based catalysts are widely applied for C2-C4 production owing to their minimal methane selectivity, ability to produce short-chain unsaturated hydrocarbons and oxygenates [11], adaptability to varying H2/CO ratios [9]. However, Fe-based catalysts face challenges such as carbon deposition under high-temperature syngas conditions and sintering, leading to deactivation [12–15]. According to relevant studies, the Boudouard reaction (2 CO → C + CO2) is the main reaction leading to carbon deposition [12,16–19]. This accelerated carbon deposition rate not only leads to the evolution of the Fe active phase but also disrupts the balance between carbon deposition and elimination during the reaction, causing rapid catalyst deactivation and alterations in product selectivity. In general, supported catalysts synthesized by the immersion method exhibit high initial activity, but the Fe introduced in this way predominantly exists as clusters or large FeOx particles. The water-gas shift (WGS) reaction on the surface of these catalysts is intense, a with over 30 % of the CO reactants typically converted to unwanted CO2 [20], resulting in reduced carbon atom utilization. With increasing time on stream (TOS), the activity of these catalysts decreases and the product distribution changed, indicating progressive deactivation and changes in catalyst performance [21,22]. The strategy to reduce carbon deposition nucleation is to decrease the size of precursor Fe2O3 precursor [11]. To enhance Fe dispersion, SiO2 [23,24], ZnO [25], TiO2 [26] and Al2O3 [27] are often added to the catalyst as structural accelerators or as spacers. Carbon carriers such as activated carbon, carbon nanofibers (CNF), carbon nanotubes (CNT), carbon spheres [28] and Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs) [29] have also been widely reported as carriers of iron-based FTS catalysts [30]. ZSM-5, a microporous zeolite with MFI topology, exhibits a high specific surface area that promotes the effective dispersion of metal species and exceptional structural stability under elevated temperatures, pressures, and water vapor exposure, making it a commonly used support for FTS active phases [31–35]. Traditionally, Al-doped ZSM-5 has been extensively employed as a support or bifunctional catalyst in FTS, primarily due to its strong Brønsted acid sites that facilitate the production of C2-C4 hydrocarbons, aromatics, and long-chain hydrocarbons (C5+) [32,33,36–40]. However, such acid sites, which simultaneously promote cleavage, isomerization, and polymerization of reaction intermediates, presents a significant challenge in precisely controlling product selectivity. Additionally, conventional Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts inevitably lead to the formation of Fe agglomerates and sintering, which are characterized by excessively large particle sizes and polydisperse size distributions. These inherent limitations have motivated our investigation into Fe-doped pure silica ZSM-5, which features uniform Fe species in its framework. This structural characteristic is anticipated to facilitate the formation of highly dispersed FeCx active sites through suitable post-treatment processes. Herein, we report the synthesis of a Fe-doped pure silica ZSM-5 catalyst with high Fe content and further investigate the dynamic evolution of framework-incorporated Fe species during high-temperature template removal. In particular, the carbonization of Fe species under the reaction atmosphere was studied in detail. Compared to the conventional Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst obtained by the impregnation method, the Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst demonstrates exceptional stability, high C2-C4 hydrocarbons selectivity, low CO2 selectivity, and resistance to carbon deposition and sintering. All reagents were used directly without further purification. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tetrapropylammonium bromide (TPABr, AR), iron chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6 H2O, AR), and silica (29–31 % SiO2 in water, AR) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH, AR) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Synthesis of Fe-ZSM-5: The metal Fe was incorporated into the zeolite framework by in-situ doping, and the template agent was removed by calcination while Fe was extracted from the original framework positions ( Fig. 1). FeCl3·6 H2O (0.9 g), H2O (17 mL), TPABr (6.65 g) and silica (16.64 g) were added to a beaker. After thorough stirring, NaOH solution (2.5 mL, 10 M) was added dropwise to the mixture. The resulting gel was transferred to autoclave reactor and crystallized in a 180 °C blast drying oven for 72 h. The autoclave was then left at room temperature for 24 h. The solid was centrifuged, washed to neutrality, and dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The obtained solid was denoted as Fe-ZSM-5 (T). It was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C (2 °C/min) for 5 h, and the resulting solid was denoted as Fe-ZSM-5. The Fe content in the catalyst was determined to be 3.91 wt% by ICP-OES. The synthesis steps for ZSM-5 (without Fe) were identical to those for Fe-ZSM-5, except that no iron salts were added, and the NaOH (10 M) dosage was adjusted to 2 mL. The resulting white solid was denoted as ZSM-5. Synthesis of Fe/ZSM-5: Fe/ZSM-5 was prepared via the impregnation method with a target Fe loading of 3.91 wt%. A 50 mL beaker containing H₂O (30 mL) was used to prepare an Fe³ ⁺ solution by dissolving FeCl₃·6H₂O (0.7580 g). ZSM-5 (3.8436 g) was added to the beaker, followed by the Fe³ ⁺ solution, and the mixture was stirred for 1 h. The beaker was placed on a heating plate at 80 °C and stirred until the water evaporated. The obtained solid was dried in a blast drying oven at 110 °C for 12 h. The sample was heated in a muffle furnace at 550 °C (2 °C/min) for 5 h. The resulting brick-red solid was denoted as Fe/ZSM-5. The Fe content in the catalyst was also confirmed to be 3.91 wt% by ICP-OES. 2.3 Characterizations All spent catalysts were stored in a nitrogen-filled glove box prior to characterization. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a Bruker AXS-D8 diffractometer to determine the structural composition and phase distribution of the catalysts. Ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-Vis-DRS) measurements were conducted on a PerkinElmer LAMBDA 850 spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was conducted using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed using a Bruker INVENIO spectrometer to characterize the functional groups of the catalysts. Thermogravimetric (TG) was conducted using a Setaram Labsys Evo simultaneous thermal analyzer under an air atmosphere. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted using a Hitachi SU8010 microscope. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) was conducted using a JEOL JEM-2100F electron microscope. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 physisorption analyzer. 2.4 FTS test The reduction and carbonization process, and FTS processes were conducted in a high-pressure fixed-bed reactor. The catalysts were treated to obtain particles of 40–60 mesh (275–425 μm). A mixture of 0.5 g catalyst and 0.5 g quartz sand was loaded into a quartz tube liner (inner diameter: 12 mm) within the reactor. Prior to the reaction, syngas (H₂/CO molar ratio = 2:1, pressure = 0.5 MPa, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) = 10800 mL·h⁻¹ ·g⁻¹ ) was introduced. The reactor was heated to 440 °C (2 °C/min), reduced and carbonized for 6 h. A mixed feed gas (N₂/H₂/CO molar ratio = 1:6:3) was then introduced under the following conditions: 320 °C, 2.0 MPa, WHSV = 4000 mL·h⁻¹ ·g⁻¹ . Nitrogen was used as an internal standard gas to calculate CO conversion. After stabilizing the syngas for 1 h, the temperature was increased to the target temperature to initiate the reaction. Online gas chromatography was employed to analyze gaseous products. CO conversion and product selectivity were determined based on carbon content, with carbon balances exceeding 96 % in all cases. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Texture and phase identification of fresh catalysts To investigate the texture and Fe species distribution of the two catalysts, a series of characterization was conducted on the catalysts prior to the reaction ( Fig. 2). XRD was utilized to identify the phase structure of synthetic materials (Fig. 2a). The typical MFI structural phase (JCPDS No. 44–0696) was observed at 2θ values of 8.0°, 8.0°, 8.8°, 23.1°, 23.7°, 24.4°. Both spectra exhibited consistency, indicating that the introduction of heteroatoms did not affect the synthetic phase. The peak intensity slightly decreased after Fe doping, possibly due to enhanced X-ray absorption caused by the introduction of Fe components [41]. The Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst displayed diffraction peak at 33.2° and 35.6°, which were assigned to the Fe2O3 phase (JCPDS No. 33–0664). However, no phase of Fe was detected in the XRD pattern of Fe-ZSM-5 (T), signifying that Fe species were extremely dispersed in the framework and did not form large crystalline phases on the zeolite surface (Fig. 2a, Fig. S2). UV-Vis-DRS is a primary method for analyzing the presence of framework Fe in zeolites [42–47]. The absorption bands related to ligand-to-metal charge transfer (CT) are susceptible to coordination geometry and environment, allowing for identification of the Fe oxidation state based on their spectral positions. This aids in understanding the migration process of Fe (Fig. 2b). Specifically, the absorption band of framework Fe ranges from 200–250 nm; isolated Fe and oligomeric extra-framework Fe in zeolite pores appear at 250–350 nm; larger Fe clusters are observed at 350–450 nm; and absorption bands above 450 nm correspond to bulk FeOx particles [47]. In practice, framework Fe shows two CT bands at 211 and 245 nm, corresponding to isomorphic binding, tetrahedral coordination Fe3 + within the zeolite framework, associated with t 1→t 2 and t 1→e conversions [43,44]. Experimental results indicate that Fe-ZSM-5 (T) displays intense CT band positioned at 247 nm in the spectrum, while the band near 211 nm is nearly undetectable, suggesting an altered coordination environment of Fe. In one study, the dual-spectrum and single-spectrum absorption of zeolites were attributed to the absorption of Fe3+ in the coordination environment of perfect tetrahedrons and twisted tetrahedrons (T d) [42]. The absorption band in Fe-ZSM-5 (T) moves towards a longer wavelength of about 261 nm, indicating Fe migration in the framework. In another study, the absorption spanning 300–400 nm in Fe-ZSM-5 (T) was attributed to octahedrally coordinated Fe³ ⁺ in oligomeric FeOx [45,46]. Upon removing the template at high-temperatures, the absorption band broadens and exhibits strong absorption from 200 to 450 nm, indicative of isolated Fe, oligomerization, and Fe cluster formation outside the framework. The Fe/ZSM-5 absorption band is primarily observed in the 300–600 nm, with the strongest absorption at 400 nm, corresponding to both Fe clusters and bulk FeOx (Fig. S3). H2-TPR is employed to assess the reduction temperature of metal oxides and assess interactions among the components (Fig. 2c). The area under the peak reflects the extent of phase reduction, while the position indicates the level of difficulty in phase reduction [48]. One study established the dependence of reducibility on grain size, indicating that larger grains require higher reduction temperatures [49]. Fe/ZSM-5 exhibits a continuous reduction process in the 400–700 °C region. These processes correspond to the reduction process of Fe3+→Fe2+→Fe0 [50]. We attribute the broad peaks ranging from 300 to 450 °C in Fe-ZSM-5 to the continuous reduction of small-sized Fe particles located outside the framework from Fe³ ⁺ to Fe⁰. The peak over the 650 °C to 750 °C range represents the reduction behavior of framework Fe, which is accompanied by the continuous migration to form the extra-framework Fe. FT-IR spectrum of Fe-based ZSM-5 zeolites at 25 °C reveals the existing forms of Fe (Fig. 2d∼g). In the Fe/ZSM-5 spectrum, the two absorbance bands at 586 and 492 cm−1 are attributed to Fe-O stretching vibrations [51–53], demonstrating the presence of the α-Fe2O3 phase. A wide-ranging absorption band near 3476 cm−1 can be assigned to the superposition of the stretching vibrations from OH⁻ groups and H2O molecules, and the band at 1640 cm −1 belongs to the OH− bending vibration adsorption [54]. Absorbance bands at 3476 and 1640 cm−1 indicate the presence of adsorbed H2O molecules [53]. The absorption band around 3600 cm−1 is typically ascribed to the Brønsted O-H group [55]. However, a distinctive band at 3676 cm−1 emerges in Fe-ZSM-5 after template removal, attributed to Fe-OH stretching vibrations [55,56]. All Fe-OH groups are associated with extra-framework species, indicating the migration of Fe from the framework [55]. This observation indicates the existence of framework Fe in Fe-ZSM-5, consistent with the UV-Vis-DRS and H2-TPR results (Figs. 2b and 2c). Through Electron-microscope images, the zeolites were clear observed ( Fig. 3). SEM images revealed that both catalysts exhibited a spherical aggregate morphology. The Fe/ZSM-5 consisted of homogeneous micron spheres with a size of approximately 3 μm, while the Fe-ZSM-5 appeared as spheroids ranging in size from 1 to 8 μm. Higher-resolution subfigures reveal the detailed structures of the zeolite microspheres. The Fe/ZSM-5 microspheres were composed of layered zeolites stacked with closely interconnected layers, while the Fe-ZSM-5 microspheres consist of aggregates of nanocrystals exhibiting distinct intercrystalline voids. The disparity in microscopic morphology indicates the existence of framework Fe significantly influenced the crystalline synthesis of zeolite, with its existence being the primary factor contributes to the formation of small-sized crystals. The morphology of independent zeolites and the aggregation state of the Fe phase were further observed using HR-TEM. Fe species nanoparticles of varying sizes were uniformly supported on the Fe/ZSM-5. Fe-ZSM-5 (T) was clustered together with highly ordered pores, and no Fe-species nanoparticles were observed on the zeolite, indicating a high dispersion of Fe within the zeolite framework. However, dense and uniform clusters of about 2 nm were found in TEM images of Fe-ZSM-5. This change visually demonstrates evidence for the extraction, migration and aggregation of framework Fe at high-temperatures. A separate study also reported less than 1 nm Fe clusters were observed in calcined Fe-silicate microbeads [57]. Selected-area electron diffraction (SAED) revealed that the Fe particles formed through migration are predominantly composed of Fe oxides. All fresh zeolites exhibit large BET surface area (Fig. S4, Table S2). The median pore diameter of all samples was close to 0.55 nm, indicating the prominent structural features of ZSM-5 [58]. All samples showed significant adsorption at low P/P 0 values, which was related to micropore filling. The H4-type hysteresis loops are observed in all samples at relative pressure levels higher than 0.4, attributed to the existence of intergranular mesoporous. These characteristics are typical of microporous zeolite polycrystals. Compared with ZSM-5, Fe/ZSM-5 showed a reduced BET surface area, which is caused by the blockage of pores by Fe2O3 nanoparticles, and the reduction of micropore volume also corresponded to this observation. However, the total pore volume of Fe/ZSM-5 remained constant because of the increased contributions from intergranular mesoporous volume, which was confirmed by the SEM images. (Fig. 3b). Additionally, the color of the fresh catalysts provided further evidence of differences between the samples (Fig. S1). ZSM-5 shifted from white to brick red after ferric chloride impregnation, a distinctive characteristic of Fe(Ⅲ) oxide. After template removal, Fe-ZSM-5 transitioned to a slight yellow tint, likely due to mass transfer and oxidation of the extra-framework Fe. In summary, the characterization results demonstrate the migration of framework Fe in Fe-ZSM-5 during high-temperature calcination. Fe migrated from the zeolite framework to pores and outer surfaces, forming a highly dispersed FeOx phase. This process provides a foundation for the formation of uniformly sized FeCx active phases during reactions. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts after reduction and carbonization For Fe-based FTS catalysts, Fe species often exist in the form of FeOx, and the generation of FeCx requires carburizing pretreatment. The catalysts were carburized at 440 °C, 0.5 MPa, H2: CO = 2:1, WHSV = 10800 mL/h. After carburizing for 6 h, the samples were taken out for SEM and TEM characterization ( Fig. 4). Through Electron microscope images, the carbon deposition and active phase Fe5C2 produced were more directly observed (Fig. 4). The SEM images reveal that there are significant differences between Fe/ZSM-5 and Fe-ZSM-5 after reduction and carbonization. Fe/ZSM-5 zeolite spheres are composed of stacked nanosheets, whereas Fe-ZSM-5 is constituted of aggregated crystals. Thus, Fe-ZSM-5 is more prone to form intergranular mesoporous. Many nanotube-like substances appeared on the surface of Fe/ZSM-5 after treatment, which was a large number of carbon species that grew during the treatment. No carbon deposition was found in the SEM image of Fe-ZSM-5 after reduction and carbonization. HR-TEM images more clearly observed the change of catalysts after carbonization. The separation of Fe species from zeolite and aggregation around zeolite have been observed on Fe/ZSM-5. We believe that this change is related to the complex carbonization environment (synthesis gas atmosphere at high temperature and pressure). Local magnification TEM images revealed the formation of Fe5C2 species in Fe/ZSM-5 (Figs. 4d and 4e). In contrast, no detectable carbonaceous deposits were observed in Fe-ZSM-5. Upon further magnification analysis, abundant Fe nanoparticles (∼5–15 nm) were found uniformly distributed within intercrystalline voids of Fe-ZSM-5. Electron diffraction analyses confirmed these nanoparticles comprise Fe5C2 and Fe3O4 phases. These Fe particles originated from FeOx cluster (∼2 nm) precursors existing prior to reduction-carburization treatments. Under high-temperature reductive carbonization conditions, these FeOx clusters detached from the zeolite framework and subsequently migrated/agglomerated into intercrystalline FeCx nanoparticles. The confined mesoporous dimensions between zeolite crystals effectively restricted sintering of FeCx species into larger aggregates, thereby enabling formation of relatively uniform Fe nanoparticles. 3.3 FTS performance of catalysts The both catalysts demonstrated outstanding performance in the FTS reaction ( Table 1), exhibiting high selectivity for C2-C4 hydrocarbons, approaching the 56 % limit of ASF in the polymerization mechanism [59,60]. Typically, Fe-based FTS catalysts show CH4 selectivity higher than 30 %, while both catalysts displayed much lower selectivity for CH4. For comparative analysis of CH4 selectivity, representative data associated with Fe5C2 as the predominant active phase in FTS were compiled (Table S1). The Fe-ZSM-5 showed lower CO2 selectivity (15.62 %) at approximately the same CO conversion after 24 hours, which is about 54 % lower than that of Fe/ZSM-5. The activity and stability are important criteria for measuring the effectiveness of a catalyst. In the reductive environment of FTS at elevated temperatures and pressures, the catalyst may undergo phase transformation or structural reconstruction. This change typically occurs in the early stages of the reaction, but over time, the catalyst stabilizes and reaches dynamic equilibrium. The CO conversion of the two catalysts exhibited significant disparities within 100 hours ( Fig. 5a). The performance of Fe/ZSM-5 showed significant variation throughout the reaction, which can be categorized into three distinct stages. In the first stage, the conversion rose sharply to 40 % in the first 4 h. In the second stage, the conversion gradually dropped to 30 % between 4 and 9 h, followed by another rise to 36 % between 9 and 20 h. In the third stage, the catalyst was not stable after 20 h and was rapidly deactivated up to 100 h. The conversion rate of Fe-ZSM-5 initially increased to 31 % within the first 15 hours of reaction and subsequently remained stable at around this level for the remainder of the reaction. Within the first 100 hours of Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst operation, its exceptional stability ensured that the product selectivity remained essentially unchanged (Fig. 5b), while maintaining a high CO conversion. The total selectivity of C2-C4 hydrocarbons consistently ranged between 54 % and 55 %, with the selectivity of CO2 consistently maintained at a low level. 3.4 Characterization of spent catalysts The structural and phase changes of spent catalysts are crucial for clarifying deactivation mechanisms and the role of iron carbide (FeCx) in product selectivity. The spent Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst retained its crystallinity, indicating robust structural stability under reaction conditions. By contrast, the spent Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst experienced a moderate reduction in crystallinity while maintaining the MFI topology, likely due to partial framework degradation (Fig. S6). SEM and TEM images revealed the structure and phase of the spent catalyst more directly ( Fig. 6). SEM images showed that carbon filaments grew extensively on the surface, resulting in the Fe/ZSM-5 being fully covered. The spent Fe/ZSM-5 appeared as a black, massive material resulting from the deposition of numerous carbon species and high-temperature sintering (Fig. S7d). After exposure to air, the spent Fe-ZSM-5 underwent a rapid color change from gray to yellowish, with no discernible carbon species present in its appearance (Fig. S7c, Fig. 6b). TEM images revealed that Fe particles (40–80 nm) on the surface were spatially separated from the Fe/ZSM-5 zeolite and encapsulated by abundant carbon filaments. SAED analysis confirmed the predominant presence of the Fe5C2 phase in these particles, with minor detection of the Fe3O4 phase associated with the WGS reaction. By contrast, the Fe-ZSM-5 exhibited smaller Fe5C2 particles (10–30 nm) enveloped by carbon shells (∼6.5 nm thick). These Fe5C2 nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed within the intergranular regions of the zeolite, with individual active sites physically segregated by zeolite crystals. Notably, no extraneous carbonaceous deposits were observed on the external zeolite surfaces. The differing stability of both catalysts is mainly attributed to the deposition of carbon species. To evaluate the quantity of carbon deposited on the spent catalysts, TG tests were conducted after 100 h of reaction ( Fig. 7). Between 50 and 900°C, the mass loss of the both spent catalysts took place in two stages under air atmosphere. From 50–140°C, the spent catalysts absorbed moisture from the air, triggering a mass increase. Subsequently, as the temperature rose, the moisture was gradually eliminated. From 250 and 500°C, the carbon species were decomposed and removed. At this stage, the weight loss of Fe-ZSM-5 amounted to merely 6.6 %, which was significantly lower than the 25.5 % of Fe/ZSM-5. The TG data, in conjunction with electron microscope images, demonstrate that Fe-ZSM-5 exhibits a weak carbon deposition capacity, thereby greatly enhancing its stability. Fe-ZSM-5 demonstrates stable operation for over 100 hours while maintaining high conversion rates, attributed to the absence of carbon deposition and sintering. We attribute this phenomenon to its unique characteristics. First and foremost, the dispersion state of the precursor Fe species plays a pivotal role. The FeOx cluster precursors were highly dispersed across the zeolite surface, promoting uniform aggregation of FeOx clusters. This facilitates the formation of small-sized Fe5C2 particles with consistent dimensions under syngas conditions. Secondly, the inter-crystalline mesopores within the polycrystals impose a confinement effect on the Fe5C2 particles. This confinement restricts the Fe5C2 particles to the inter-crystalline spaces, effectively preventing their aggregation and fusion into larger particles—a process known as sintering—thereby significantly stabilizing the particle size of Fe5C2. Thirdly, uniformly small-sized Fe5C2 exhibited a reduced CO dissociation capability. As a result, the concentration of C* generated from Fe-ZSM-5 remains limited, ensuring a delicate balance between carbon deposition and carbon removal [61]. Lastly, the carbon shell confinement effect in the Fe5C2@C core-shell structure is indispensable. The formation of the carbon shell effectively traps C* within the shell, substantially curtailing its ability to escape and form additional carbon deposits [61,62]. The combined effects of these characteristics contribute to the long-term performance stability of the Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst. In addition, the excellent hydrophobicity of the carbon shell prevents the further oxidation of Fe5C2 to Fe3O4, thereby significantly reducing its CO2 selectivity [30]. The formation of carbon shells on FeCx surfaces in FTS catalysts primarily originates from carbon species deposition. This process exhibits inherent complexity governed by multiple mechanistic pathways. Carbon deposition arises predominantly through two distinct routes: (1) CO dissociation and surface carbon accumulation [63–65]. On Fe-based catalyst surfaces, CO undergoes dissociation: CO → C* + O*. Unpolymerized C species progressively aggregate, dehydrogenate, and consolidate into amorphous or graphitic carbon layers. (2) Boudouard reaction [64,66,67]. Under elevated temperatures (>250 °C) or reduced H2/CO ratios, the Boudouard disproportionation reaction occurs: 2CO → C + CO2 (ΔH < 0), directly generating elemental carbon deposits. 3.5 Adaptability of catalysts The impact of reaction temperature and H2/CO ratio on CO conversion and C2-C4 hydrocarbons selectivity is particularly significant ( Fig. 8). The reaction temperature is an essential parameter that impacts the catalytic performance of catalysts (Fig. 8a and Table S3). As the temperature increases, the number of activated molecules increased, leading to a rise in conversion from 13.58 % to 57.76 %. The CO2 in FTS products was mainly produced by the WGS reaction and CO disproportionation reaction. The enhancement in conversion brought about an enhancement in by-products such as H2O, resulting in the oxidation of FeCx to Fe3O4. The oxidized Fe3O4 acted as the active center of the WGS reaction, triggering a considerable boost in CO2 selectivity. Furthermore, with increasing temperature, the cracking behavior of long-chain products was intensified, resulting in the increase of CH4 and C2-C4 hydrocarbons selectivity while the decrease of C5+ selectivity. The variation in the H2/CO ratio of syngas significantly impacted catalyst selectivity (Fig. 8b and Table S4). With the augmentation of H₂/CO ratio, the product distribution shifted from long-chain hydrocarbons to C2-C4 hydrocarbons, and the O/P (C2-C4) gradually decreased. The effect of WHSV on product selectivity is also critically significant (Fig. 8c and Table S5). A lower WHSV corresponds to longer reactant residence times, which enhances CO conversion. However, olefins are not hydrogenated into paraffins under these conditions, thereby increasing the olefin-to-paraffin ratio. As WHSV increases, CO selectivity slightly decreases, and the product distribution shifts toward shorter-chain hydrocarbons. The effect of varying Fe contents in Fe-ZSM-5 on the catalytic performance of FTS were investigated (Table S6). The excess added Fe could not enter the framework, and impaired the formation of Fe-ZSM-5 (Fig. S5). When the Fe content is 4.96 wt%, the selectivity for CO2 experiences a leap-like increase, with CO2 selectivity between of 3.91 Fe-ZSM-5 and Fe/ZSM-5. We believe that both framework Fe and extra-framework Fe coexist in 4.96 Fe-ZSM-5 (Fig. S8 and Fig. S9). All samples exhibit a relatively white appearance when the Fe loading is below 3.91 wt%. However, the 4.96 Fe-ZSM-5 displays a dark yellow color, distinct from the brick-red hue of Fe/ZSM-5 (Fig. S1b). This pronounced color difference implies the presence of iron in an extra-framework oxidation state. UV-Vis-DRS analysis of 4.96 Fe-ZSM-5 further confirms the simultaneous existence of framework Fe and extra-framework Fe (Fig. S9). In the 4.96 Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst, distinct absorption in the 200–600 nm wavelength range indicates the coexistence of both framework and extra-framework iron species [47]. As the Fe content increases, a higher density of active sites is exposed. The H2O by-product increased alongside the growth in CO conversion, the oxidation of FeCx intensified, and the WGS reaction associated with CO2 production was enhanced. A higher Fe content resulted in larger Fe nanoparticles, which increased chain growth capacity and shifted product distribution toward heavy hydrocarbons. In an effort to introduce aluminum species into the ZSM-5 framework, we synthesized FeAl-ZSM-5 by substituting 10 % of the Fe content with Al (Table S7). This modification was strategically designed to leverage the acidic properties of aluminum for enhancing C2-C4 olefin selectivity. However, contrary to our expectations, the partial substitution with aluminum exhibited detrimental effects. The incorporation of aluminum not only resulted in reduced CO conversion rates but also demonstrated an inhibitory effect on the formation of C2-C4 olefins during the catalytic process. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we demonstrated that Fe species in ZSM-5 can migrate from the framework to form highly dispersed FeOx clusters (∼2 nm) during high-temperature template removal. These FeOx clusters acted as precursors enabling the formation of small-sized Fe5C2 particles during carbonization, ultimately resulting in an inter-crystalline confined Fe5C2@C core-shell structure. The small Fe5C2 particles exhibit weakened CO dissociation capability, maintaining a low concentration of C*, while the carbon shell further suppresses carbon deposition by confining these species. The resulting Fe5C2@C structure, free from intercrystalline carbon deposits, endowed Fe-ZSM-5 with exceptional stability and sustained product selectivity over 100 hours of operation. Moreover, the hydrophobic carbon shell inhibits the WGS reaction, significantly reducing CO2 formation by ∼56 % compared to conventional Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts. Our findings offer novel perspectives on the design of Fe-based FTS catalysts with low CO2 selectivity and underscore the importance of highly dispersed Fe precursors for achieving efficient and sustainable FTS processes. coredata.dc:description: Under the dual pressures of oil depletion and low-carbon transition, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) technology offers a viable option for producing high value-added lower (C2-C4) hydrocarbons from non-oil sources. However, conventional Fe-based catalysts often suffer from deactivation due to carbon deposition and sintering. Here, we report a unique Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst synthesized by doping Fe into ZSM-5, which demonstrates excellent FTS catalytic performance. During high-temperature template removal, Fe species migrated from the zeolite framework to form highly dispersed FeOx clusters (∼2 nm). Upon treatment by syngas, these FeOx clusters aggregate to form uniformly small-sized Fe5C2@C core-shell particles distributed on ZSM-5 support. The confinement effect of the inter-crystalline structure effectively prevents the sintering of Fe5C2. The smaller Fe5C2 particles exhibit controlled CO dissociation, reducing the concentration of activated carbon species (C*), and the carbon shells (∼6.5 nm) limit the departure of C*, effectively suppressing carbon deposition. This unique structure enables stable catalytic activity for over 100 hours with maintained product selectivity. The Fe-ZSM-5 catalyst achieved a C2-C4 hydrocarbons selectivity of 54.52 %, nearing the 56 % theoretical limit of the Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution. Additionally, the hydrophobic carbon shell prevents excessive oxidation of Fe5C2, reducing CO2 selectivity by ∼56 % compared to conventional Fe/ZSM-5 catalysts, significantly enhancing atomic utilization efficiency and aligning with the principles of green development.
